biogHist.abstract: Care Leavers Australia Network (CLAN), founded in 2000 in Sydney, is a support and advocacy group for people brought up in care away from their family as state wards or children raised in Children's Homes, orphanages or other institutions, or in foster care. CLAN is also for anyone who has a close family member who was placed in 'care'. The founding members of CLAN are Leonie Sheedy and Joanna Penglase, both 'care leavers' who had for years been involved in awareness-raising about the issues facing people who experienced out of home 'care' as children.

descriptiveNote.p: CLAN spent years lobbying the Australian government for an inquiry into children in institutional care.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Opening presentation by Vladimir Selakovic, Care Leavers of Australia Network (CLAN)

archref.unittitle: Opening presentation by Vladimir Selakovic, Care Leavers of Australia Network (CLAN)
archref.abstract: This is a transcript of the presentation given by Vlad Selakovic at the 'Archiving: moving forward as a community' workshop at the Victorian Archives Centre, North Melbourne. Vlad shares his perspectives on accessing his government records relating to his time in institutional 'care' as a child.
archref.note: Published with the kind permission of the author

resourceRelation.relationEntry: The advertisement that started it all

archref.unittitle: The advertisement that started it all
archref.abstract: This is a framed copy of a newspaper ad placed by CLAN's co-founder Joanna Penglase seeking participants for her research into children's homes.
archref.note: Permission to use or reproduce part or all of this image must be sought from the Care Leavers Australia Network (CLAN)
